I’ve placed one in different rooms and love being able to get things done without having to stop, play and pause with different devices or blasting music from one room to listen throughout the house. It’s unfortunate that HomePod doesn’t support the ring doorbell. But it’s safe to say I’ve dropped all of my Alexa echo devices and have happily transitioned to the HomePod. I’m looking forward to the HomePod mini for the kid’s rooms and guest room. Although I can’t play directly from 3rd party apps directly, yet, it’s still a great device and I’ve recommended it to my friends. It’s a bit bulky but well worth it!

author: Anonymous
content:
Apple makes a great product and I am part of the ecosystem. I was comparing this to a sonos one and ended up going with the Sonos because the sound quality was superior. 

I bought this to use in my home office mainly for music.
I’m not a fan of Siri and I use Spotify for music, so this was strictly about sound quality and ease of use for me. 

The HomePod sounds great and is well designed, but it is still overpriced and didn’t sound as good as I thought it would (not that it sounded bad). This would be a great value at $200, but not at 300 and def not 350 where it started at. 

 As a Spotify user, I also noticed how much of a difference the sound quality is when streaming it natively as opposed to using airplay and that was another point for Sonos. 

This may be a good device for HomeKit users, but I didn’t need a smart speaker (already on Google’s eco) and not an Apple
Music subscriber, so this didn’t fit my use case. I’m glad I tried it out for myself though.

author: Franc
content:
I was excited to buy HomePod when I read it had several internal speakers. The design is elegant and minimal that exemplifies the Apple signature. However, in hindsight, I would not be so quick buy it if I was aware of its shortfalls. 

Here is why:
1. Does not connect with the Apple TV smoothly. The volume breaks while watching a film or does not come on at all. Makes for unpleasant experience and not be able to enjoy the engineered volume design. 
2. Siri does not connect to other Apple devices. If you ask it to set an alarm, it would set alarm on the pod not the iPhone. Hardly useful, specially when the alarm volume on the pod is so maimed to wake you up from deep REM sleep. 
3. It does not have connection to home app that we have come to be accustomed to from Apple. It is limited when it comes to controlling o smart lights for instance. 

I recommend to wait until Apple irons out the kinks in the next HomePod models. It’s too $$$$ not to have the all inclusive experience. If it is the sole function of the speaker you desire, there are reputable speakers with much less price tag.
title: Well design at its infancy

author: CABREWSKI
content: The HomePod seems to still fly under the radar for smart speakers. People always ask about them at my house and most have never seen or heard the HomePod before. A lot of people also don’t know about HomeKit and Siri built into it. However, they are always impressed by the sound and quality of the HomePod. I purchased a HomePod from Best Buy to make a stereo pair with on I already had. With the price reduction of $199 on sale which Best Buy has run every few weeks like clock work, the HomePod is more affordable than ever and is a must buy at its current reduced prices. AUDIO FEATURES While one HomePod sounds great, a stereo pair is where this speaker really shines. The soundstage is large and the audio is warm and balanced. Music has rich, deep bass accompanied by crisp, smooth highs and a balanced midrange. Out of the box, the eq settings are perfect and the microphone placements inside analyze the surrounding environment in which they are placed to automatically adjust the EQ of the speaker. As you move it throughout the house, it shines in an open setting or against a wall where it will pump out loud and clear sound without clipping. With a stereo pair (you can pair them in the Home app), the music is then sent as LEFT and RIGHT channels and the quality is unparalleled. You can even pair them with Apple TV for amazing home theatre quality mimicking surround sound or soundbar setup. Music and TV audio will fill the room perfectly. They are plenty loud in any placement and they sound just as good at a higher volume without distortion. You can also handoff audio playing on your iPhone by simply holding your iPhone next to the device. Your iphones audio will seamlessly transfer to your HomePod without interruption. You can then hold your phone next to the HomePod to have the audio transferred back to your iPhone. You can also stream any airplay capable audio to the speakers from your MacBook or other apple device by selecting the HomePod in the airplay drop down menu. SMART FEATURES The HomePod features a touchscreen on the top of the speaker that recognizes certain gestures like the Echo or Google Home devices. The HomePod has no physical buttons, but illuminated to reveal a volume up and down touchpad and a singular circle touchpad in between them that you can tap to pause, play, and skip songs. You can also accept or reject phone calls on the HomePod and utilize the HomePod to talk on the phone. The microphone quality is great - on the phone you come across extremely clear and “Hey Siri” is almost always recognized in any part of the room you say it. Of all my smart devices, this one recognizes my voice more than any other device and I don’t have to yell or repeat myself to get it to recognize me. The HomePod is integration of Siri is where the speaker leaves a lot to be desired. You can use the Siri function just as you would on your phone. You can set alarms, send texts, make calls, ask it to play music, and ask some basic questions such as metric conversions or “Who is Nicholas Cage”. If you’ve used Siri, you’ll know that it is an AI far behind Alexa and Hey Google. Complicated questions confuse it and it often can’t answer simple questions that Alexa and Google are able to answer. Apple is constantly improving Siri, but I use my Google Nest Hub far more for my everyday questions. If you are a HomeKit user, you can control your smart home with the HomePod. HomeKit, however, has far fewer applications where it useful and it is still pretty bare bones in comparison with its counterparts. For my smart home functions Philips Hue, ecobee, SimpliSafe etc, I prefer to use my google home and Alexa. The functions of HomeKit are limited and until it gets better, it is much easier to use another AI for controlling my home. Even though Apple is serious about its smart home integration with the HomePod, it just isn’t useful yet. So if you’re looking primarily for a smart device, choose something else. CONCLUSION For most people that buy the HomePod are aware of this and they buy it for it’s best quality, its speaker. It is far better than any other speaker in my house, and head to head with the Home Max and Echo Studio, it is miles above them with unparalleled sound quality. For the price, it is the best speaker you can buy and you won’t regret the absolutely amazing sound quality. As a stereo pair, it is much better than some of the top speaker brands at a fraction of the cost. Siri is great for asking it to my shuffle my playlists or play certain albums and the hands free nature of being able to ask for music is great. The design is beautiful - the minimalist look fits well in any space and the cloth covering is much more appealing than plastic or other alternatives that many speakers use. It is very much a signature Apple device that is still underrated. If you are looking for incredible sound in a small and reasonably priced device, you cannot get any better than the HomePod.

author: Luke
content:
The quality of these speakers outshines most others. The home automation ecosystem has been lacking due to this being the only option up until late 2020. Siri, despite what haters may claim, works just as well as the multitude of Alexas we have around the house. The Homepods definitely take the cake on sound quality, even by comparison to Amazon’s highest end Echo Studio and Sub combo. It is on par with the more expensive Sonos units; but you can get HomePods for $199 if you catch them on sale and, thus, this makes them a better value than compatible Sonos. Sonos has the benefit of a large ecosystem full of a myriad of options.

The call quality on these is superb, second to know, it may even be their best feature. People on the other end are completely unaware that I’m not talking on my phone. I’ve also been on the other end of these calls and can attest to this observation. It is simply astounding how well they isolate your voice. This definitely surpasses Alexa, Google, and even similarly priced Sonos units.

It also integrates much better with our home automation on a grand scale than our Alexa units; working with more lights and smart home devices overall. We just simply have more Alexas due to cost. We use the pair of HomePods exclusively for music and phone calls due to this fact.

However, I’m only rating this as 5 stars with the knowledge that the ecosystem is FINALLY expanding with the Mini; if not for that, this would probably get 4, maybe even 3, stars. Apple simply waited too long to break out of this single-unit shell.
title: Flawless call quality, limited ecosystem

Also because i bought two for my loft, I’d like to play both of the same thing music without setting them as Right and Left speakers because they’re in different “rooms” in the loft, but that can’t be done without using AirPlay. Bf and I used his Sonos throughout the loft before and it worked great. Never had an issue with connection or setting it up as individual Or paired speakers. author: IBoughtAThing
content:
At first I was going to rate this a 3/5 because I was using it in my small office (6x8) and it was a little overpowering for the small room, especially sitting on the desk top. My main purpose for it is sound, I don't care at all about the Siri functions. I'll just keep using my power computer speakers in that room for now.

So I moved it out into a large kitchen/family room and integrated it in with 4 in-ceiling speakers in that room by putting it across the room on a shelf, and it tied in quite well and improved the sound drastically. The bass is significantly improved and makes the in ceiling speakers sound way better.

It sounds great in the kids bedrooms - way better than the little portable battery powered ones they currently use. We've set up an Apple TV & monitor on a desk in one empty room as a 2nd tv watching area and it works great for that. 

It's impressive how good it sounds alone but would probably be pretty amazing if paired with another in a stereo configuration, so that's likely in the future. I'd like to compare it to a Sonos airplay compatible set for similar pricing though.

If I could perform a lobotomy on it and take out Siri I'd like it better. I use "hey Siri" on my phone extensively while driving on hands free. Then I come home and do a fast and easy calculation like "hey Siri what's xxxx plus xxxx" and it stops working on my phone and the HomePod answers from across the room up on a shelf "I'm sorry, I can't do that", while my phone Siri is silent. I think I can disable it but the control interface isn't super great.
title: Sounds really great but had to grow on me

author: wrbluepearl
content:
TL; DR: The HomePod is super easy to set up and use with your iPhone.  It even sounds pretty good.  A good value if you get it on sale.

Setup: Take it out, plug it in, and use your iPhone to configure it.  Yep, that's it.  Takes like 10 seconds.

In use: I'm an Apple Music subscriber, and using Siri to control it works *fairly* well. For some reason, Siri doesn't understand a request for Boston's "Hitch A Ride", but otherwise seems to do a good job of figuring out what I'm asking for. One gripe is that the HomePod is essentially a 'separate device' as far as Apple Music is concerned; it would be nice to have the option of seamlessly continuing a playlist or song that's playing on your phone on the HomePod - obviously, there's a manual way to do this by using the HomePod as an Airplay destination, but it would be even nicer if it were automatic/seamless.

Sounds quality-wise, it's good but not amazing - I'd say it sounds as good as a Sonos One, but each has its own pluses/minuses.  The HomePod sounds a little 'bassy' to me; the bass is good, well-controlled, and has some texture, but there's just a little too much of it.  Mids and highs are fairly clear and well-defined.  Gets pretty loud without distorting or vibrating, which is nice.  However, my KEF LS50s in the other room aren't feeling threatened.
title: Convenient and sounds decent

You then go to the music app to pause audio or adjust volume or change song and NOPE... you have to go into the Home app to do that. Totally makes sense Apple... NOT.

author: Atimm
content: From reading the reviews, I expected this thing to immediately blow me away. It didn’t, but I had to give it a proper chance. I put it in a different spot that was more open from obstructions, and gave it a shake to recalibrate its audio scan feature. I played another song and noticed it was sounding a bit better. It’s about 6in from the wall on a shelf 3ft off the ground with some small decor around it. It’s in my bedroom so I wanted it at a height that would reach above the bed. Well, I laid in bed on my laptop while I had some music playing on the HomePod. I noticed it sounds fuller and more balanced when you’re about 6+ feet away from it. Up close, it’s loud and clear, but no depth to the sound. When at this 6-8 foot distance, you can actually notice the HomePod filling the room and the walls resonate with bass. At that point, I was actually impressed this was coming from the little black speaker on my tv stand. I listened to various genres of music, and some bass-lines in LoFi music made me smile. How can something so small and simple make the room seemingly vibrate around me? HomePod is best for someone looking for an always ready speaker to cast your music/audio to from your Apple device. Siri isn’t the brightest AI, but she can make phone calls, send/read texts, and control your smart home well enough. HomePod is for those that love to listen to music and experience proper sound quality while doing so. If you seek brains over sound quality, check out Google’s offerings.

author: nostupiding
content:
When the HomePod came out I was a bit skeptical, especially at it's normal price point. But this is now my third that I have purchased. I bought this one for use in my guest bedroom. The other two are in the Master Bedroom and my office at work. 

Hands down, the sound quality cannot be beat by anything else in this size package. I was blown away by the quality. It's got enough volume for listening to music in almost any situation. It's perfect for a bedroom or office. For outdoor use or larger party environments there are some larger speakers from Sony I'd recommend... but for just wanting some great sounding music and the ease of saying "Hey Siri, play me some..." it can't be beat. 

Setup is the easiest of ANY smart speaker I've used IF you're in the Apple ecosystem. I have Google smart speakers and/or displays in every room room of my house and all my lighting is Philips Hue. The HomePod was by far the easiest to setup. And although Siri is not as "smart" as Google Assistant, the microphone quality on the HomePod is far better at catching commands from a distance, and I get far fewer errors with the HomePod. Often times my other smart speakers don't hear me without shouting, or they hear something different than what I said. The HomePod hears me every time and more accurately, even with music at a fairly loud volume, than any other smart speaker I've used. 

So although Siri can't do as much as Google Assistant, when I interact with my smart speakers in my home, I much prefer interacting with the HomePod. And setup was so much easier (if you're already an Apple user). I do plan on replacing all my other smart speakers in every room with HomePods when my budget permits me to do so.
title: Was skeptical at first... Love it now!

author: Yoga
content: I have been intrigued by this product since released, and frustrated with Apple's pricing practices and desire to be a "top tier" company by only offering high end high price products. This device always seemed a bit overpriced and unnecessary for me as I have a nice sound system connected to my TV, but I wanted something for Home Kit control. I like Apple's focus on encryption and privacy especially with the alway on always listening home controlling devices like this. I have apple Home Kit enabled devices in my house, and wanted a quick way for my pet sitter to turn them on and off when she comes in. I tried the Amazon dot last year, but found it difficult to setup and you need to have the always listening feature on. It also required setting up my already existing already working HomeKit enabled devices in the Alexa app which was hit and miss. I was waiting and hoping that Apple would release a cheaper version of this with less speaker and more control. Then Best Buy had this on holiday sale for 100 dollars off retail price. I figured it was worth a try knowing I had time to return it if it did not work. I set it up in seconds yesterday, and immediately transferred the podcast I was listening to on my phone to the speaker. I often wear headphones around the house and listen to music or podcasts throughout the day. This makes it easy to transfer what I am listening to via my phone airplay button and I can hear it clearly from anywhere in the downstairs. It sounds amazing and is so much easier to use to listen to anything on my phone. Yes you can use it without the Hey Siri feature listening. You can press and hold the center of the top panel which prompts Siri so I can turn off the "always listening" or if it does that annoying digital assistant thing where it mishears something I say that sounds vaguely like "Hey Siri" and becomes disruptive (This has not happened yet). I also like that in the Home app on my iPhone I can turn off the Home pod analytics which will not share my always on always listening recordings with Apple or anyone else. I wish the $200 price was not a promotion, but the retail price. After 1.5 days it has proven its worth and made me realize something I was overtly critical of and uninterested in is as good as I was sure it was not. I like being proven wrong. I am not sure I would pay $300 for it at full price, but if it keeps impressing me like this I might eat those words as well.
title: Good

author: centurion
content: This is my first so called smart speaker and I have been hesitant because of privacy concerns, you're basically buying a microphone/speaker hybrid with a processor connected to the internet all the time - 1984 Orwell, anyone? I decided to nevertheless give it a try. Most of my devices operate within an Apple ecosystem, so the choice was obvious. I love what this little thing can do after I was finally able to set it up, but it was a nightmare. It is something designed to operate seamlessly as a Wifi based device. However, the first speaker would not connect to my Wi-Fi no matter, how hard I tried. I spent 3 hours on the phone back and forth with Apple technical support, which basically advised me to reset, unplug everything back and forth. They are usually good for other devices but for this one they turned out to be useless. I have a great Link-sys Wi-Fi 6 router with WPA2/WPA3 mixed personal security settings and network quality is excellent. After 3 hours, Apple capitulated and told me the device was defective and advised me to return it to Best Buy. I returned it and exchanged it for a new unit. In the meantime, I discovered on my own that the Best Buy Unit had an old software and also read on the internet that people who were having trouble were able to connect it to a guest network. When I exchanged the device for a new unit, it had the same problem, would not connect to Wi-Fi. I created a guest network, connected the HomePod and updated its software. Then I switched the iPhone I set it up with from guest network to my regular network. HomePod switched along with it but still would not do personal requests. I then reset the HomePod and set it up again and it worked like a breeze. Maybe yours will set up easily like most, mine didn't and if I were not persistent, I would not enjoy it. You can use it as your digital secretary, make appointments, reminders, play music, radio, news, ask for stuff, fun. It is the first iteration of a primitive AI digital secretary and music player, in 10 years I expect it will do a whole lot of things for you :()
title: Very interesting device

The downside is her connection issues. She constantly drops my connection or is choppy. Update to HomePod has not helped much.

It also does not integrate well with any non apple service. So you can play Spotify and Soundclound but you can not start those apps with voice control.

author: AdamE
content:
The speaker has great, great sound for its size (not too big). The bass bumps. Awesome sound quality.
Having said that, the software interface is incomplete. It disconnects when it wants. If I’m playing Apple Music, and move to YouTube, the audio does not follow, meaning the speaker will continue to play Apple Music while my iPhone plays YouTube.
Sometimes the volume control button on the iPhone doesn’t control the speaker, it controls the iPhone volume. You have to go into the app that is playing music for the volume to work.
Having said that, I will keep the speaker. It went on sale for $200, so it’s almost worth the price.
I would say that, as it’s released right now, that the speaker is worth $150.
I hope that Apple fixes the interface, the iPhone communication, and the overall sound connectivity between applications. It is do able. Again, the hardware is there, and I give it 10/10 based on the hardware alone. But the software interface/connectivity, and the high price tag, drops it to 3/5.
I don’t use the smart features (Siri) so won’t comment on that.

author: Bsavy
content: So I wanted to educate my house and make it a Smart Home (Lol).  I researched speakers and found that Alexa and Google were the probably the most popular do to price and ease of use.  I don't think Apple pushes this product as much as they should.  With that being said, i now have four(4) HomePods throughout my house.  I simply say "Hey Siri"  and tell her to do something and its done as if it was on my phone or IPad.   Controls my Apple TV, Phillips Hue Light Bulbs,  Easily connects into the Apple Homekit, as with all Apple products.  So my Apple Watch, Earpods, AppleTV, HomePod, and IPad are all synced (as are my entire families devices).  The Homepod is your IPhone or IPad without a screen.  Instead it has a speaker that has great top of the line sound. Its competing with Bose and Cerwin Vega,   What you lack in loud distorted bass.  You make for with clean "full" sound.  The HomePod still gets pretty loud and the fact that you can sync them to all play the same music from the same device or have each speaker playing different music from different devices makes it even better.  The only down side to this speaker is that i needs to be plugged in, but this is not a portable speaker it is a home speaker.  Perfect for an Apartment, Dorm, and/or any room in a house.  Its an Apple Product and if you like Apple this lives up to Apple Product hype.   Again, did i mention i now have four (4).
title: Quality Sound!!!!! Solid Smart Speaker,

author: SCLoop
content: The HomePod has the best sound of almost any similar sized streaming speaker, especially when you pair it with another HomePod.  With that said, one of my units only lasted 18 months. I also have many Sonos products for my whole home system, some of which are now over 10 years old.  They work perfectly and have not given me any trouble.  In addition, the Sonos system connects and plays instantly and every time.  The HomePods often will not connect to my phone via Airplay causing me to restart my phone or the HomePods several times. The HomePod seems to not work well with a mesh wifi system and does not recognize that the iPhone and the HomePod are on the same network. I am a big user of many Apple products and I have usually had a great experience.  Other than the excellent sound quality of the HomePods, I am very disappointed with the functionality and quality of this product. A $300 speaker should last more than 18 months.

author: JasperDyne
content:
This is the perfect accompaniment to a subscription to Apple Music (a free 3-month trial comes with purchase if you aren’t). Once the initial setup is completed, just ask Siri to play a song, album or playlist and boom! You’re getting good sound with rich bass. Volume can be controlled with voice commands, or the virtual buttons on top of the unit.

Things get more complicated if you’re not an Apple Music subscriber.

If you have an iPhone, all you need to do is start your music playing, and tap your phone to the top of the unit and your music is automagically transferred to the HomePod via Airplay.

Any AirPlay enabled device should be able to stream to HomePod, so if you have an AppleTV, you can stream audio with a couple of taps.

You can link two HomePods together for stereo sound.

An update coming in Fall of 2020 promises better integration with third-party music services like Spotify.

If you’re not in the Apple ecosystem, there are better, cheaper speaker systems with equal sound quality and more flexibility (like Sonos).
title: If You’re Deep Into The Apple Ecosystem, Get This

author: NewHomeNightmare
content:
The HomePod emphasizes sound quality more than smarts.  
It’s most useful to think of the HomePod primarily as a high-performance wireless speaker that is voice-controlled and to consider its “smart” features as secondary.

Audio:
Apple stuffed this device with loads of sophisticated audio components—seven tweeters, a high-excursion subwoofer, and six microphones—as well as, to make it all work, one of Apple’s own A8 chips, like those used in iPhones.  The result is an excellent deep, rich audio that sounds fantastic.  The speaker is easy to set up and effortless to use, as long as you're playing Apple Music.

Smart features:
You can’t make calls to phones or other HomePods or create calendar appointments, or make use of any of the 15,000-plus smart skills (like games, Uber or Lyft requests, pizza delivery, and more) that have powered the popularity of Alexa or Google Home platform.
title: Great speaker that's not so smart...yet

Being an Apple Music subscriber, using Siri on the HomePod to play music and playlists that it would think I would like has been nothing short of a treat. I find the music recommendations great and the sound quality unmatched in a smart speaker.

Although Siri has gotten a bad reputation, I find Siri is more than adequate for most queries and actions. Again comparing it to my two echo dots, I actually prefer Siri for 99% of things. I have found Siri to have less hangups, especially when making music requests. Apples app “Siri shortcuts “does make customizing what you request from Siri better. However the app can be a bit daunting to novice users. And Siri’s response when responding to custom commands can sometimes be robotic. I have found that Siri is far quicker than Alexa at controlling smart home devices. 

Having loved the HomePod so much, when they were on sale again, I picked a second one up. I set them up in stereo mode and was again very impressed by the sound that it put out.

Ideally,  I would have a HomePod on each floor of my home. Due to the higher price of the HomePod, the cost can be restrictive to making that a reality. While I have two set up on one floor in a stereo pair, it is easy enough to move one or both to another floor or a room, plug it in, and have it play without doing anything else. 

The HomePod works best with Apple Music, but with the upcoming update in the Fall of 2020, Apple will be allowing third party music support on the HomePod. Although it is possible to do so now by air playing to the speaker from your phone, you must still rely on the phone to do so. The new update should allow third party services to run natively. 

The HomePod is a device for people that want smart home control, with the advantage of privacy that Apple offers, along with a love and appreciation for music. If music is not a priority, there are currently cheaper alternatives to dedicate to smart home control. For music lovers and those in the Apple ecosystem, the HomePod is a great choice.

author: Aidan
content:
The HomePod seems to still fly under the radar for smart speakers. People always ask about them at my house and most have never seen or heard the HomePod before. A lot of people also don’t know about HomeKit and Siri built into it. However, they are always impressed by the sound and quality of the HomePod. 

I purchased two HomePods awhile back from Best Buy. I snagged open box deals for both of them, considering the original introductory price was a hefty $349. That put the HomePod in the same range of top of the line smart speakers such as theGoogle Home Max, the Echo Studio and Sonos One. With the price reduction now of $199 on sale, the HomePod is more affordable than ever and is a must buy at its current reduced prices. 

AUDIO FEATURES
While one HomePod sounds great, a stereo pair is where this speaker really shines. The soundstage is large and the audio is warm and balanced. Music has rich, deep bass accompanied by crisp, smooth highs and a balanced midrange. Out of the box, the eq settings are perfect and the microphone placements inside  analyze the surrounding environment in which they are placed to automatically adjust the EQ of the speaker. As you move it throughout the house, it shines in an open setting or against a wall where it will pump out loud and clear sound without clipping. 

With a stereo pair (you can pair them in the Home app), the music is then sent as LEFT and RIGHT channels and the quality is unparalleled. You can even pair them with Apple TV for amazing home theatre quality mimicking surround sound or soundbar setup. Music and TV audio will fill the room perfectly. They are plenty loud in any placement and they sound just as good at a higher volume without distortion. 

You can also handoff audio playing on your iPhone by simply holding your iPhone next to the device. Your iphones audio will seamlessly transfer to your HomePod without interruption. You can then hold your phone next to the HomePod to have the audio transferred back to your iPhone. You can also stream any airplay capable audio to the speakers from your MacBook or other apple device by selecting the HomePod in the airplay drop down menu.  

SMART FEATURES 
The HomePod features a touchscreen on the top of the speaker that recognizes certain gestures like the Echo or Google Home devices. The HomePod has no physical buttons, but illuminated to reveal a volume up and down touchpad and a singular circle touchpad in between them that you can tap to pause, play, and skip songs. You can also accept or reject phone calls on the HomePod and utilize the HomePod to talk on the phone. The microphone quality is great - on the phone you come across extremely clear and “Hey Siri” is almost always recognized in any part of the room you say it. Of all my smart devices, this one recognizes my voice more than any other device and I don’t have to yell or repeat myself to get it to recognize me. 

The HomePod is integration of Siri is where the speaker leaves a lot to be desired. You can use the Siri function just as you would on your phone. You can set alarms, send texts, make calls, ask it to play music, and ask some basic questions such as metric conversions or “Who is Nicholas Cage”. If you’ve used Siri, you’ll know that it is an AI far behind Alexa and Hey Google. Complicated questions confuse it and it often can’t answer simple questions that Alexa and Google are able to answer. Apple is constantly improving Siri, but I use my Google Nest Hub far more for my everyday questions. 

If you are a HomeKit user, you can control your smart home with the HomePod. HomeKit, however, has far fewer applications where it useful and it is still pretty bare bones in comparison with its counterparts. For my smart home functions Philips Hue, ecobee, SimpliSafe etc, I prefer to use my google home and Alexa. The functions of HomeKit are limited and until it gets better, it is much easier to use another AI for controlling my home. 

Even though Apple is serious about its smart home integration with the HomePod, it just isn’t useful yet. So if you’re looking primarily for a smart device, choose something else. 

CONCLUSION
For most people that buy the HomePod are aware of this and they buy it for it’s best quality, its speaker. It is far better than any other speaker in my house, and head to head with the Home Max and Echo Studio, it is miles above them with unparalleled sound quality. For the price, it is the best speaker you can buy and you won’t regret the absolutely amazing sound quality. 

As a stereo pair, it is much better than some of the top speaker brands at a fraction of the cost. Siri is great for asking it to my shuffle my playlists or play certain albums and the hands free nature of being able to ask for music is great. The design is beautiful - the minimalist look fits well in any space and the cloth covering is much more appealing than plastic or other alternatives that many speakers use. It is very much a signature Apple device that is still underrated. If you are looking for incredible sound in a small and reasonably priced device, you cannot get any better than the HomePod.

author: MacTulare
content:
First off, understand that the HomePod acts as its own device and not really an extension of your iPhone. 

You can airplay to the HomePod from your phone but the HomePod will take over the source leaving your phone open to play it's own music. You can control the HomePod from your phone but you have to specifically select the HomePod in the Music app to do so, by default the Phone will show what it is playing on the phone and not the HomePod. Is this a problem, not really but it does take some getting used to.

The HomePod will sync to your AppleID so you can access your calendar etc BUT it has its own app for alarms and does not sync to you phone alarms. Viewing the set alarms on your phone is stupid, yes stupid as you have to open the Home App and then open the HomePod. 

I get the sense that Apple is trying to force you to use Siri to control the HomePod. If this is your thing then you won't have any issues. I had to adapt to using Siri for everything. Also Siri is no Alexa so don't expect it to act like Alexa. Siri is simply not that smart and can't handle commands or actions like Alexa. If you know Siri's limitation's you won't be disappointed. 

The sound is amazing! Really more than what I expected. 

My final verdict- I'm going to get another one when Best Buy drops the price back to 199.
title: Know what you get and don't get with the HomePod

author: RachiMayes
content:
Before I go deep into this review. Remember: I’m deep in the Apple ecosystem. 

I did my research before buying this HomePod just to make sure this is what I wanted. So after tugging with the price and the wallet strings, I finally got one when the price went down(On an excellent open box!)

This thing is heavy! All those speakers in a round speaker that look sleek is crazy! Had to order the tabletop stand because the speaker can ruin furniture(Read in reviews)

I set it up at my mom’s house just to see what it sounds like. As a person who likes his sound coming out of any speaker to be clear and hit on every note I will say this......OMG! Apple nailed it on this unit. Every note. Every time.  

(Just to prove it, if you get one....play Feel The Bass Part One by DJ Majic Mike to test it out)

It has the capability of controlling anything in your house with the right comparable equipment. 

Downside: Need iPhone to setup and Apple Music subscription. Only pulls music from the ecosystem including any music you have in iCloud. Not Bluetooth. Have to know how to hit those taps just right on the unit to get it to work right and it’s highly sensitive.

But it sounds great! If you are a Apple user and like top quality sound, then get this for your living room and or bedroom.

author: Mitch
content:
The HomePod received a lot of critical feedback at its initial launch, and in some cases rightfully so, but this is a FANTASTIC smart speaker for those in the Apple Ecosystem. I originally bought, and returned, a HomePod a year and a half ago and regretted it shortly thereafter. The recent sale was too good to pass up on however, so I took the dive again and will likely be buying a second.

I have had Google Home devices scattered (mini's, normal Homes, a Home Hub, and a Home Hub Max) in my home for years due to wanting smart speakers, but not wanting Amazon devices. Privacy has become more important to me over time, and I have become more entrenched into the Apple ecosystem over the years as well. The HomePod sounds absolutely incredible, and is FAR more reliable as a smart home hub than the Google Home's we have had which constantly have issues connecting with our Philips Hue, and August Smartlock. The HomePod and Homekit never have issues controlling our smart home, and perform tasks much more quickly than our Google devices. Pair the better performance with better sound, and much more privacy due to how Apple handles requests on the HomePod and this is an easy choice to make. As is normal, the build quality is fantastic, and it looks great in any space.

My main wish is that a HomePod mini and Google Home Hub like device is released so that I can replace my Google Home's entirely. Sure, the Google Assistant is smarter when it comes to random search requests and internet type searches, but for what I use my smart devices for 95% of the time, the HomePod is actually BETTER.
title: Fantastic

author: EnzoM
content: I’m an Apple user through and through so, homepods (I bought two on sale) make sense for me. My wife and I have iPhones, Apple TV’s throughout the house, iPads and Apple watches. Ahem! Apple... you got us. So, homepods make sense for us compared to other smart speakers for that reason among others. I happen to like Apple’s privacy policies better than googles or anyone else’s. If you’re going to have these devices in your home “listening” to you all the time, I prefer that they’re Apple devices. I bought two of them and connected them as a stereo pair in our living room and they do sound pretty dang good. I have an actual stereo/hifi multichannel systems upstairs in my theater room. The homepods certainly can’t match the stereo imaging/sound of that system but, with careful, precise placement, they do offer good stereo imaging and sound. Not great, not spectacular, but good for what they are which are small smart speakers after all so, expectations in check. For their size/weight they sound very impressive and even at very high volume they don’t sound at all stressed. I first tried a single homepod but as our living room is medium to large in size and open to the kitchen/dining area, it didn’t fill the space as I had hoped. Set up as a stereo pair fixed that problem and I can hear them pretty much anywhere in our home. They’re very even sounding with no real peaks or dips overall. They just sound good. The Siri function works perfectly almost every time too. Siri’s well known limitations compared to other virtual assistants not withstanding. We subscribe to Apple Music (naturally) and that service works perfectly via the homepods. As we’re “Apple people”, they work for us and we’re quite happy with them especially as we picked up two of them at a substantial discount while on sale. Back to stereo for a sec, I have noticed that they can sound great with “audiophile” tracks. YouTube is not an audiophile streaming service, but when I play audiophile quality music from YouTube there is an improvement in airiness, delicacy and separation and vocals sound better too. So, they can sound very good on certain high quality tracks even over less than audiophile quality streaming services like YouTube. The homepods are smaller than I thought (or remember) but pack a solid punch in sound quality. Great product and we’re happy with them. Now, let’s hope Siri gets a huge update to finally bring it up to par with the other virtual assistants.
title: Love em’, but I knew what I was getting...

author: Briandb03
content:
The sound from this puppy is wonderful. Its ability to assess its surroundings and project room-filling sound is impressive. It’s quite heavy which helps give the bass some added “oomph.” It is best experienced when used in conjunction with an Apple Music subscription. One irritation is that it doesn’t seem to be able to begin a playlist in the middle and play forward from there. It must start at the beginning and play the songs in order. Passing off music from an iPhone to the HomePod isn’t always seamless, either. 

I liked the sound so much that I bought a second one. They were able to quickly identify each other in the HomeKit app and play well together. However, I must admit that it turns out I was fine having only one HomePod. I’d hoped to have one in front of the living room and one in back so that I would feel even more immersed by the sound. However, that isn’t really how it worked out. Instead, one gets assigned as the left channel, and one the right. Both really need to be in front of you for the best combined effect. Our apartment isn’t large, so a singe HomePod would have been fine. I suppose that a person in a larger home would find it beneficial to have one upstairs and one downstairs, but that isn’t our living situation. We’ll likely give our second one to a friend.

The HomePod  isn’t as smart as an Alexa. Instead of being able to add “skills,” many functions my be airplayed from an iPhone to the speaker, rather than the speaker being able to do it by itself. An easy fix would be for most iPhone apps to have HomePod versions the same way they do for the Apple Watch. The functionality through the HomeKit app is clunky and not as intuitive as you would expect from Apple. The Apple Watch and the HomePod don’t seem to communicate well, either. The watch and the HomePod don’t seem to be on the same page, as the watch is showing different music playing than what the HomePod is actually playing. If you tap the HomePod in the HomeKit app on your watch while the HomePod is playing, you don’t gain access to HomePod controls. Rather, the HomePod starts playing whatever music was on the watch. 

The HomePod can serve as a speakerphone so I was really eager to use that functionality for when we call family.  Unfortunately, the caller on the other line seems unable to hear clearly unless you really raise your voice or literally sit right next to the speaker. I’ve tried speaking to several callers to make certain the issue wasn’t because of one person’s phone. I learned that the issue was always a problem. Perhaps the microphone isn’t as attuned to voices during phone calls as it is to voices speaking commands to it.  
 
I know I’ve listed several complaints in this review, so I want to reiterate that this is an EXCELLENT speaker if you want room-filling sound with rich bass and crisp treble. But this is supposed to be smart and functional, too. Apple is usually too customer oriented to allow a product to be deficient for long. They like to make products that “just work.” Therefore, I’m hoping that future software updates will make it smarter and more user friendly.  If they do that, I’ll give it all five stars. It’s an expensive piece of equipment so it really should do more things more easily.
title: An excellent speaker, just not so smart.

author: tjb007
content:
I bought this for my spouse to use in her salon for music. Previously she was using a Google Home speaker, so she was due for a sonic upgrade. And the HomePod definitely produces better sound than a Google Home, no question. But unfortunately, the speaker just didn't work well for her. 

Her biggest problem was caused by plugging her Square mag-strip card reader into her iPhone while music was playing. No matter what she tried, plugging the Square reader into her iPhone made music on the HomePod pause (I assume the either the phone or speaker saw the Square reader as headphones or an audio device being plugged in). I tried to fix it, but couldn't ever figure it out. It drove her nuts though, especially since the old Google Home never had this problem. She is the type to just want things to work and be simple, and saying "Hey Google, play my salon mix" is about as easy as it gets. 

After a month with it, the pausing issue was on her last nerve. She decided to return it and she put that money towards a Dyson hairdryer, and resumed using the Google Home for her music needs. 

My second, and more general, gripe is the price. I purchased the HomePod in December 2019. At that time, there was a holiday price of $199. I think, sound-wise, that $199 is the right price for this speaker. Don't get me wrong, it sounds great, but it still sounds like a bluetooth speaker, which means a limited soundstage and some lack of clarity (particularly the highs and mids). It's just inherent in the design of a small object stuffed with speakers, you get a small footprint in exchange for a lack of clarity or separation. In my opinion, $299 would be much better spent on a pair of Sonos Ones in a stereo configuration, placed apart from one another. You'll get better stereo separation and a wider sound stage with a pair of Sonos versus the HomePod. You can also keep adding Sonos speakers as you see fit, to service multiple rooms or even create a surround system. Lastly, it is also worth mentioning that the HomePod is already a 2 year old product. Sure, it sounds great for a bluetooth speaker, and it does sound better than my $139 JBL Charge 4, but it doesn't sound TWICE as good.  If you pay more than $199 for this is in 2020, you're paying too much. 

In conclusion, if you must own a HomePod, wait for it to be on sale. $199 is a fair price for a 2 year old bluetooth speaker, but $299 just isn't a fair price anymore when you can get two Sonos One speakers for a dollar more. Also, if you're getting this for a similar use-case as my spouse, don't be surprised if using your iPhone for other activities while streaming music to the HomePod causes problems for you.
title: Great sound, but price and small quirks overwhelm

author: MusicFi117
content:
Yes, this speaker only works if you have an apple device, but if you're looking for a great wireless speaker that streams over WiFi instead of bluetooth, HomePod is the way to go! I love it and it can pick up my voice from a distance to either make it play music or even turn up the volume while it's playing. I have no issues with it yet. It does what I bought it for and it's so nice being able to play music now from my bed without having to get up and turn something on and having to connect my phone. 

I have my speaker setup next to an old 2.1 computer speaker setup in my room and one day my dad thought my music was playing from my 2.1 setup. He couldn't believe the sound was coming from just the HomePod. It's heavy and for a good reason! It puts out a good amount of volume and great quality sound. According to Amazon Music's app, the HomePod is playing at 24bit/48kHz for it's maximum streaming quality. I have a Hi-Fi setup in a separate room with studio monitors and an Onkyo receiver as well and the HomePod is still a great substitute when I don't feel like turning on my whole Hi-Fi setup.

I highly recommend the HomePod based on my experience, but you definitely have to first consider how you plan to use your wireless speaker and what you need from it. But again, for my needs it's been perfect and I have no regrets! I wish it was completely wireless being that it needs to be plugged in to work at all, but again that's what makes it able to put out the sound that it can.

author: Chava
content: I have been intrigued by this product since released, and frustrated with Apple's pricing practices and desire to be a "top tier" company by only offering high end high price products. This device always seemed a bit overpriced and unnecessary for me as I have a nice sound system connected to my TV, but I wanted something for Home Kit control. I like Apple's focus on encryption and privacy especially with the alway on always listening home controlling devices like this. I have apple Home Kit enabled devices in my house, and wanted a quick way for my pet sitter to turn them on and off when she comes in. I tried the Amazon dot last year, but found it difficult to setup and you need to have the always listening feature on. It also required setting up my already existing already working HomeKit enabled devices in the Alexa app which was hit and miss. I was waiting and hoping that Apple would release a cheaper version of this with less speaker and more control. Then Best Buy had this on holiday sale for 100 dollars off retail price. I figured it was worth a try knowing I had time to return it if it did not work. I set it up in seconds yesterday, and immediately transferred the podcast I was listening to on my phone to the speaker. I often wear headphones around the house and listen to music or podcasts throughout the day. This makes it easy to transfer what I am listening to via my phone airplay button and I can hear it clearly from anywhere in the downstairs. It sounds amazing and is so much easier to use to listen to anything on my phone. Yes you can use it without the Hey Siri feature listening. You can press and hold the center of the top panel which prompts Siri so I can turn off the "always listening" or if it does that annoying digital assistant thing where it mishears something I say that sounds vaguely like "Hey Siri" and becomes disruptive (This has not happened yet). I also like that in the Home app on my iPhone I can turn off the Home pod analytics which will not share my always on always listening recordings with Apple or anyone else. I wish the $200 price was not a promotion, but the retail price. After 1.5 days it has proven its worth and made me realize something I was overtly critical of and uninterested in is as good as I was sure it was not. I like being proven wrong. author: Mikey2103
content:
I'm an Apple fanboy, yet there's one issue I have with this amazing smart speaker.  For sound, it's top notch and better than any other smart speaker out there, IMO.  The bass punches and the clarity is spectacular. If you buy two of these and make a stereo pair, expect to be amazed.  This speaker is a no brainer for Apple people and if you're patient, it usually goes on sale at BB every few months where you can snag it for $199.  When this happens, snatch the babies up. 
Now for my one main issue, and it has nothing to do with quality of sound.  I wish so badly that there were an Apple speaker that had an HDMI ARC port and could hook it up to your tv.  This way you could have true surround sound with these speakers much like the way Sonos works.  I only have one of these Homepods due to this reason and I have way more Sonos speakers around the crib.  Each of my flat screen tv's have a Sonos Beam synced up with two Sonos One SL's.  They're sound is good but if I had the option to replace this setup with Homepods, I would in a freaking heartbeat.  Maybe it's good that I can't cause that would destroy my wallet trying to replace the One SL's with Homepods.  But who knows, maybe if a miracle happened and Sonos and Apple had a collab... haha and we're all going back to our normal lives within a week (cough, Corona virus).  I would give these Homepods 5 stars and beyond if I could set them up as surround speakers for a TV but that just ain't where we're at.  If you do have an Apple 4K TV you can go into your video and audio settings and set the Homepods as the audio source but it's a pain to have to do that each time you turn on the device.  Not worth it in my opinion.  Anyway, if you plan on using the Homepod strictly for music then you're definitely getting your money's worth.
title: Amazing sound with one limitation

author: HappyHomePoduser
content:
Christmas present to myself. I mostly wanted it for music, possibly more Home kit stuff in the future. works well for me. I use lots of Apple products and services so I find it easy to use and convenient.

I got my first one from BB for $200 - new on sale. (Probably would not have paid the regular price of $299.) I liked it so much I went back and bought a second one to setup a stereo pair in my living room. Sounds very nice for that listening space.

A good wifi internet connection in the room where you place it is needed otherwise you are unlikely to find it useful. Mine occasionally looses the internet and needs to be reset (I unplug the unit wait a few seconds and plug it back in. Open the Home app on my iPhone and check settings. Sometimes it is checking for/waiting for an update).

I use iTunes Match and can ask Siri to play any of my hundreds of albums or any of the thousand of individual songs I have uploaded to my iTunes Match account and the HomePod plays them. I love the instant voice activated access to all of my music. Also works with my Apple TV if I want to use the HomePods for my TV sound output.

Good product if you know what you are buying and what the current and future uses are/will be with new Home kit functionality and new compatible devices becoming available.

author: ycables76
content: I have been intrigued by this product since released, and frustrated with Apple's pricing practices and desire to be a "top tier" company by only offering high end high price products. This device always seemed a bit overpriced and unnecessary for me as I have a nice sound system connected to my TV, but I wanted something for Home Kit control. I like Apple's focus on encryption and privacy especially with the alway on always listening home controlling devices like this. I have apple Home Kit enabled devices in my house, and wanted a quick way for my pet sitter to turn them on and off when she comes in. I tried the Amazon dot last year, but found it difficult to setup and you need to have the always listening feature on. It also required setting up my already existing already working HomeKit enabled devices in the Alexa app which was hit and miss. I was waiting and hoping that Apple would release a cheaper version of this with less speaker and more control. Then Best Buy had this on holiday sale for 100 dollars off retail price. I figured it was worth a try knowing I had time to return it if it did not work. I set it up in seconds yesterday, and immediately transferred the podcast I was listening to on my phone to the speaker. I often wear headphones around the house and listen to music or podcasts throughout the day. This makes it easy to transfer what I am listening to via my phone airplay button and I can hear it clearly from anywhere in the downstairs. It sounds amazing and is so much easier to use to listen to anything on my phone. Yes you can use it without the Hey Siri feature listening. You can press and hold the center of the top panel which prompts Siri so I can turn off the "always listening" or if it does that annoying digital assistant thing where it mishears something I say that sounds vaguely like "Hey Siri" and becomes disruptive (This has not happened yet). I also like that in the Home app on my iPhone I can turn off the Home pod analytics which will not share my always on always listening recordings with Apple or anyone else. I wish the $200 price was not a promotion, but the retail price. After 1.5 days it has proven its worth and made me realize something I was overtly critical of and uninterested in is as good as I was sure it was not. I like being proven wrong. I am not sure I would pay $300 for it at full price, but if it keeps impressing me like this I might eat those words as well.
title: Excellent speaker

author: Jojodancr
content:
I got this speaker to compliment my Apple TV 4K for traveling. I did not have much interest in it at the $300 price tag. However, I was able to get it open box at lower than the $200 sale price tag. I am glad I got it. 

Pros: sound is very good for the size, easy interaction with other Apple products, it can be used to make and answer phone calls, can be paired with a second HomePod and linked for better sound or multiple room configuration with Airplay 2 and Sonos products.  You can have Siri read or send texts and multiple user voice recognition, plug and play. In addition you can use the HomePod to control smart home devices, 

Cons: its a heavy speaker for the size, no external jacks available, power cord is permanently attached.
It works with only Apple Music. 
It has NO BLUETOOTH you need an iPhone or IPad to connect to it. If you are an android user I don’t recommend it but if you love Apple products like I do it’s a great addition to your Apple family. 

All in all it works great as a speaker with excellent sound quality sound and interacts great with other Apple products.

author: MacFlagg
content:
I bought several HomePods to replace Amazon Alexa’s in my home, due to privacy concerns. At first, I was pleasantly surprised by how little functionality I lost, with the help of some bridge apps, like Yonomi, Siri Shortcuts, and a piece of software I use called homebridge, I obtained off github. I was also surprised by how good they sound. I mean, they don’t sound anywhere near as good as a real home theater/hi-fi setup. But, for smart speakers, they’re leaps and bounds ahead of the others.

Unfortunately, that’s where the love affair ends. I could absolutely care less about music. I don’t even have Apple Music installed on any of my iOS devices. I consider the Music to be malware. It takes over your device every chance it gets, often ignoring the last audio source listened to, in my case it’s mostly podcasts and audiobooks, to shove music down your throat. I DISLIKE this behavior and the HomePod is completely infected with Apple Music. If the HomePod misunderstands anything, its defaults to Apple Music and tries to play a song. Just now, I was watching a tv show and the actor said, “seriously?”, and the HomePod replied, “I don’t know who is speaking,” and then started playing music. Some random song that I didn’t care for. OMG!

Then, this morning, I asked Siri, “how long will it take me to get to my next appointment?” Siri responded, “I can’t find that song,” then started playing some random music. I then asked, “how long will it take me to drive to my next appointment?” Siri responded, “traffic is light to John’s Barber shop in St Marys, so it will take about 45 minutes.” A) that is not the location of my appointment, B) I’ve never heard of or been to John’s Barber Shop and C) I don’t live in St Marys. I live in another town that is 45 minutes away. My appointment was literally 10 minutes from my house.

Using the HomePod with the Apple TV is also frustrating. One of my Apple TV’s is named Theater Tv. I can say, “pause Theater tv,” and the video will pause. Then if I say, “play Theater tv,” Siri will respond, “I’m having trouble playing your music,” then about 30 seconds later, a random song will start playing. 

Another problem is when saying, “unpause Theater tv,”  Siri will respond, “playing on multiple sources,” and will turn on and start playing music on multiple TVs throughout my home. OMG this is so annoying!

Then I tried to set up some Siri Shortcuts. I’ve got a Logitech Harmony remote and I used Yonomi to bridge Siri and the Harmony with Siri Shortcuts. I created a shortcut to turn on my projector, another to trigger the 3D Movie scene, one to control the AC unit, and another to turn on the theater room. So, when I asked Siri to, “turn 3D movie on, “ or, “ turn AC on,” or, “turn Tv room” I either got told that Siri didn’t have the capability or that there was no such room. I had to chance the names of the Siri Shortcuts to just random words and phrases to get them to work. 3D Movie became Bigtime, Tv room became just the word Maple, and AC’s became Turn Cool Breeze On. 

Then, there are connectivity issues. Just about every morning, one of my HomePods, when given a command, will respond, “Something went wrong, please try again later.” Often, rebooting the HomePod, from the Home App, fixes the issue. But every few days, one of my HomePods will have to be deleted from the Home app and re-paired to get it working again. Moreover, I get, “device not responding,” responses when trying to operate one of my HomeKit devices, by Siri on my phone can communicate with the device without issue. How is it that Siri on the HomePod is so much more incompetent than Siri on the iPhone. They should be the same, right? But, they are not. 

I called Apple to see if I could get some help and the senior tech was snarky to me and basically told me I was doing it wrong (kind reminded me of Steve Jobs telling everyone that they were holding the iPhone 4 wrong) and that I had to learn a whole new vocabulary to use Siri and that I was going to continue to have to name things random words, and remember them all, because that’s just how Siri works. He also flat out refused to troubleshoot Siri Shortcuts....Wow, just wow. 

If you’re buying HomePods just for music, I guess they’re fine. But if you’re buying them for smart home control, be prepared to be severely disappointed. This is the most un-Apple like experience/product I’ve ever had. They’re literally like disappointment and frustration generating machines. There is no delight to be found  here.

Siri is unbelievably stupid and incompetent at home control. Since home control is my primary concern, my only concern, I can’t give the product more than one star.
title: Siri is so bad, it’s truly an embarrassment

author: WoodyWoodchuck
content:
I bought a pair of HomePods from Best Buy right before Christmas when they were on sale for $199 apiece. At that price, the ability to play music (directly from Apple Music or via AirPlay from an iPhone or iPod) or sound from an Apple TV more than justified the price for the pair. (I have them set up to play as a stereo pair.) A good stereo would cost as much and saddle me with unsightly speaker wires. And the bass on these is just awesome, particularly when you figure the relatively small size.

I liked them enough that a few days after Christmas, I decided to pick up a second pair to use in another room. However, at that point the price had gone up to $300. They are nice speakers but at $200 apiece they are pricey; at $300 apiece they are way overpriced.

My advice. Wait until they go on sale for $199 either at Best Buy or at another retailer that Best Buy will price match.

As for Siri functionality, I was pleasantly surprised. She can hear me even when the HomePods are playing music pretty loudly. And most of the basic commands I’ve tried work well. Voice control of HomeKit accessories seems brisker than the same command given to Alexa. However, when I ask Siri to turn on a group of lights she does fine but when I ask her to turn off the same group, she replies, “I can’t turn off a scene.” Odd.

Where Siri still falls down is on knowledge-based requests. She still tends to want to send you the information as a link to a website you can view on your iPhone or other screen. Since  HomePod has no screen, these requests cannot be fulfilled.

The basic bottom line is these are great speakers when on sale but overpriced at full price. Smart speaker functionality is getting better all the time but still needs some work.

Oh, and you still need an iOS device to set the HomePod up, so if the HomePod is your only Apple device, you’re out of luck,
title: Great speaker but wait until they are on sale

A commonly overlooked feature is that it supports playback controls with your voice, so if you need to pause or play the tv, just ask Siri!

Keep in mind, this speaker is not a Bluetooth speaker. Apple uses Airplay 2 exclusively to deliver the highest sounds quality and greater range of connection.

author: Lisa
content:
We loved our Apple Home Pod, until it started interrupting play with a very old buzzing noise.   After trying the DIY fixes posted online we called Apple Support.  We do not have Apple Care or a close Apple Store,  but since our speaker is still inside it’s one year warranty customer service offered to send a box for us to send the speaker in for repair.  At this we were fine with that resolution. 

Unfortunately after waiting 2 weeks, the box never arrived and I had to contact customer service again.  

Since the delay was due to lack of follow up on Apples side, I asked them to upgrade my service level for this incident to Apple Care and send a replacement and I would immediately return the faulty Home Pod.  

I was VERY frustrated when not only was I refused the upgraded service to cover Apples Oversight - but the Customer Service rep refused to escalate to someone who had authority to create a better resolution due to their original service oversight.  

We have made enormous investments in Apple products and have appreciated their focus on user experience - but this experience will have us evaluating their competitors before making future purchases.
title: Loud Buzzing Noise / Poor Resolution

author: Zoosh
content:
I bought two, for a stereo set, when on sale. Figured they'd work well with my Apple devices.

The wonderful: music is beautiful, TV and films are generally fantastic. I use it primarily with my iPad Pro 12", iPhone 6s Plus both on iOS 13. Occasionally on my Mac, in the Music app.

I believe the latest iOS update improved the speakers' reliability. Classical, rock, folk, jazz - all excellent. With the improved reliability lately, I won't return them. I was otherwise considering it,

The eh: one speaker often picks up sound before the other. The lag isn't huge, just annoying. Occasionally the connection doesn't happen. I have to try a few times, both in Apple Music and using Airplay.

The speakers cut out on occassion, then resume sound.

Depending on the app, Airplay can be a nightmare. In Music, Prime Video, Netflix - rarely problems. Airplay in the Criterion Channel app sometimes works, sometimes becomes a nightmare and unuseable.

MacOS: like everyone else....why limited to iTunes? When my older MacBook eventually fails, hopefully not for a while, and if I can purchase the 16", I'd like to watch films on the newer, larger screen and use the Homepods.

Siri: gets confused. The speakers are in my bedroom. I did not purchase them for Siri but for their music quality. When my iPhone, iPad, and HomePod are in the room together, I can say, "Siri, turn off the lights," and at least two-three devices respond. The device occasionally become confused and turn the lights off, then maybe turn a lamp back on again.

author: krazygreekguy
content:
The quality of sound on a speaker this size never ceases to amaze me. The microphones’ ability to pick up you voice when talking to Siri with music playing full blast is just awesome too.

Some people tend to point out Siri is terrible or worse than Google Assistant and/or Amazon Alexa, but Siri will never be as good as those assistants as it does not collect data like they do. Also, Apple is marketing this device as a high fidelity speaker first and voice assistant second, whereas it’s the opposite for Google and Amazon. That explains the prices differences.

A couple other things to note. This speaker is geared towards Apple devices. There is no auxiliary jack or Bluetooth support, which forces the user to use Apple’s wireless streaming protocol: Apple AirPlay, which was recently updated to AirPlay 2. AirPlay 2 allows for Apple devices to stream music wirelessly to speakers or receivers that support AirPlay 2 for multi-room audio (similar to Sonos - Sonos now supports AirPlay 2), but you can use any brand speaker that supports it. AirPlay 2 uses WiFi and is much better than Bluetooth anyway, but this unfortunately does not allow non-Apple users to use the HomePod with their devices.

Pros:
-Excellent sound
-Excellent microphones
-Multi-user voice support 
-Ability to receive future software updates with new features

Cons:
-Marketed towards only Apple users
-No headphone jack
-No Bluetooth

author: baforer
content:
First I want to say that I am happy with my purchase.
The HomePod is a good sounding and reasonably competent smart speaker.
I purchased this on Black Friday and at that price I think this was a fair deal.
The things that stop this from being a 5 star review are as follows:

The reviews I read stated this as the best sounding smart speaker and this may be true, but in my opinion it is not the best sounding portable speaker. I have a Bose SoundLink Mini Bluetooth speaker that is of smaller form factor that I feel is a better sounding speaker.

As a smart speaker, Siri is ok but I have a Google Home Mini that is more competent at internet type questions. I don’t have any smart home devices that Siri or Google can control so I can’t speak to that, but the grand kids have a lot of fun asking Google stupid internet questions that Siri doesn’t handle as well. I have asked questions that Siri did not answer that Google did.

It would be nice if the HomePod supported music platforms other than Apple Music like Spotify or Pandora. Now this was not a real issue for me as I had Apple Music for free with my phone service but for other users this may be an issue.

Pluses for the HomePod.
I would like to mention that the HomePod can answer a phone and do so for multiple users. The Google Home Mini can place an internet call with a predetermined phone number For caller ID but it cannot answer a call to your phone (it can answer duo phone calls). The HomePod can place calls from your phone and answer phone calls to your phone. It does this for multiple users as it determines which phone to use by your voice. I wanted this feature so my wife can answer her phone while being busy in the kitchen which is where our HomePod is setup.

Another plus for the HomePod is that setup is so easy. Granted you have to be an iPhone or iPad user but most of the setup is copied from your iPhone or iPad. Things such as WiFi setup and Siri recognizing your voice is all taken from your device.
title: Good smart speaker, but not great

author: FrankS
content:
I have been intrigued by this product since released, and frustrated with Apple's pricing practices and desire to be a "top tier" company by only offering high end high price products. This device always seemed a bit overpriced and unnecessary for me as I have a nice sound system connected to my TV, but I wanted something for Home Kit control.  

I like Apple's focus on encryption and privacy especially with the alway on always listening home controlling devices like this.  I have apple Home Kit enabled devices in my house, and wanted a quick way for my pet sitter to turn them on and off when she comes in.  I tried the Amazon dot last year, but found it difficult to setup and you need to have the always listening feature on.  It also required setting up my already existing already working HomeKit enabled devices in the Alexa app which was hit and miss.  I was waiting and hoping that Apple would release a cheaper version of this with less speaker and more control.  

Then Best Buy had this on holiday sale for 100 dollars off retail price.  I figured it was worth a try knowing I had time to return it if it did not work.  I set it up in seconds yesterday, and immediately transferred the podcast I was listening to on my phone to the speaker.  I often wear headphones around the house and listen to music or podcasts throughout the day.  This makes it easy to transfer what I am listening to via my phone airplay button and I can hear it clearly from anywhere in the downstairs.  It sounds amazing and is so much easier to use to listen to anything on my phone.

Yes you can use it without the Hey Siri feature listening.  You can press and hold the center of the top panel which prompts Siri so I can turn off the "always listening" or if it does that annoying digital assistant thing where it mishears something I say that sounds vaguely like "Hey Siri" and becomes disruptive (This has not happened yet). 

I also like that in the Home app on my iPhone I can turn off the Home pod analytics which will not share my always on always listening recordings with Apple or anyone else.  

I wish the $200 price was not a promotion, but the retail price. After 1.5 days it has proven its worth and made me realize something I was overtly critical of and uninterested in is as good as I was sure it was not.  I like being proven wrong.  I am not sure I would pay $300 for it at full price, but if it keeps impressing me like this I might eat those words as well.
title: Excellent product, sale price should be permanent

author: charlie
content:
I wanted an assistant that could integrate with the smart lightning/devices around the house. But, I also wanted the assistant to not keep my audio in the cloud somewhere where the company/third party contractors/etc could listen to it also. 

The only choice for such an assistant so far is the HomePod, since as long as you opt out, Apple will not keep your audio in the cloud. 

I wasn't expecting much, since I've had Alexa's and Google Home around the house before and they both didn't work terribly great. However, the HomePod is remarkably better at listening to the "Hey Siri" command from everyone (from adults to children) in my household. This is even when the HomePod is playing music. 

I used to have multiple Google Homes dispersed throughout the house because Google just couldn't hear the "Hey Google" command very well. But now I just have one HomePod in the center of the house that can be used from nearly anywhere in the house. 

I don't enjoy the price as much and hope that come out with cheaper version of Siri speakers.

author: Crew
content:
Truly, my house is an almost everything Apple home. However I never thought I’d ever buy the HomePod especially at $300.  While we have home automation with Alexa and Google.  Both me and my best friend also have mostly Apple devices. We stopped in our local BestBuy and we saw the HomePod on display. We tested it out and we were hooked line and sinker.
However, once we got it setup 10 minutes and realized how freaking easy it was to setup we tested it in the home. The sensors in the device adjusts to the acoustic of the area it is placed in. We were in awe at how this device performed.  My best friend had set tumbler down with a cold drink on the same table as the HomePod and as soon as he released the tumbler the HomePod made an adjustment to the quality of sound. He picked the tumbler out of disbelief thinking it was just my imagination. And the HomePod readjust itself again and then he put it back down and the HomePod again readjust the sound. Nevertheless the HomePod not only connected to our WiFi and Apple Music account all within the 10 minutes. I am very surprised Apple isn’t selling these at a record pace.
title: Much better than expected!

author: Beto
content:
This as a speaker is good, but if you don’t use Siri often, it’s no better than buying a dedicated speaker.  I have a Bose S1 Pro speaker that is louder, but that one is more expensive.  Also, I think the Google Home speakers are louder.

If you do use Siri, this is great.  It can hear you even if you speak at normal volumes at a distance.  It works especially well if you have Apple Music, as you can ask Siri to play whatever song you want.  If you haven’t invested heavily in other Apple products, then there isn’t much appeal here.  On the other hand, if you do have iPhones, iPads, Apple TV’s, and Macs in your house, you will enjoy adding this product to the lineup.

It also holds up well over time, given that the hardware in this product is from the time of the iPhone 6 or 6s.  It still sounds good and there isn’t any lag that I’ve noticed.

author: kilowatthours
content:
I'm a long time Amazon Echo user. I love my Echo. It connect with a ridiculous number of services, and is a respectable bluetooth speaker. I haven't had a reason to switch to anything else.

Then I heard the Apple HomePod.

I'm a nerd who love tinkering so on a certain level I love the flexibility of the Echo. On a more realistic level I just never use that flexibility. I listen to music and ask silly questions to get the thing to give silly responses. I already use Apple Music and let me tell you, the Echo isn't even in the same class as the Echo speaker-wise. This. Thing. Sounds. Phenomenal. One speaker easily fills a large room with incredibly well-balanced music.

As for Siri, I honestly have struggled adopting it due to poor detection or just clumsy responses. The Siri that comes with the HomePod is ridiculously fast, and actually feels more conversational.

Now the "catch". It simply doesn't compare to other devices when it comes to integrating with other home automation devices. Compatibility is limited to HomeKit approved devices which while expanding, isn't terribly robust yet. I'm confident that this will improve (assuming Apple remains committed to this market) but I would definitely do your research to make sure your devices are compatible before buying if that's important to you.

In short, if you're in the Apple eco-system (Apple Music, Apple News, Reminders, etc.) then you can't go wrong. If you're a home automation nerd, do your research and prepare to either be disappointed or make some sacrifices. And if you just love music, just give this thing a listen. You won't regret it.
title: Phenomenal!...With a catch
